Artificial electrocatalytic ammonia (NH3) synthesis is recently becoming a research hotspot. It can couple with clean renewable electricity, which is considered an energy-efficient and sustainable approach for regulating the recirculation of nitrogen species and meanwhile promoting the growth of a circular nitrogen economy. In this Account, we review recent advances in electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis. Firstly, we briefly introduce the research background and significance of three electrochemical NH3 synthesis routes: electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction, nitric oxide reduction, and nitrate/nitrite reduction. And then we give a detailed discussion of the latest research advances in electrocatalysts for ambient NH3 synthesis, mainly involving catalytic mechanisms, theoretical advances, and electrochemical performance. Finally, the existing challenges and future research needs for artificial electrosynthesis of NH3 are also highlighted. Graphical Abstract In this account, we review recent advances in catalyst development for electrochemical ammonia synthesis in three conversion reactions (nitrogen reduction reaction, nitric oxide reduction reaction, and nitrate/nitrite reduction reaction). And challenges and perspectives are also discussed. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Nitrogen reduction Nitric oxide reduction Nitrate/nitrite reduction Electrocatalyst 1 Introduction Nitrogen (N), known as the life element, is indispensable to our lives [1]. It exhibits various valence states ranging from +3 to −5, accounting for existing in diverse forms, such as dinitrogen (N2) gas, nitrogen oxides (e.g., NO, NO2, etc.), nitrogen oxyanions (NO3 − and NO2 −), hydrazine (N2H4), ammonia (NH3), and ammonium compounds. Most of those nitrogen compounds can convert to each other through related nitrogen transformation reactions (traditionally divided into three processes: N2 fixation, nitrification, and denitrification), which is conducive to the nitrogen cycle (N-cycle) of biogeochemistry [2,3]. Nevertheless, human activities have heavily disrupted the global N-cycle, and have also ineluctably led to a series of environmental problems, which, in turn, hurt public health [4,5]. For instance, nitrogen oxides (NO x ) are poisonous atmospheric pollutants, primarily generated from the anthropogenic combustion sources in factories (e.g., power plants and industrial kilns) and traffic, and the accelerated accumulation of NO x in the atmosphere has given rise to serious environmental issues such as smog, acid rain, ozone layer depletion, and global warming [6–8]. Additionally, the overuse of nitrogen-rich fertilizers has generated high concentrations of hazardous NO3 −/NO2 − contaminants in the aquatic ecosystems, which would aggravate the deterioration of the water environment and thus harm all living systems [9]. As a result, the control of NO x emission and the removal of NO3 −/NO2 − contaminants have significant implications for maintaining the balance of the global N-cycle. NH3 is the second largest chemical produced in the world and nearly 80% of produced NH3 is employed in fertilizer synthesis, to make sustainable food production for explosive growth of the global population [10]. Meanwhile, NH3 is an indispensable raw material for manufacturing nitric acid, which can be further employed in chemical production [11]. Moreover, NH3 possesses high hydrogen capacity, making it a potential carbon-free fuel [12]. With the rapid growth of the global population, the demand for NH3 in the market keeps. However, the NH3 produced in the natural environment cannot meet the needs of human survival and development. As one of the greatest inventions, the Haber-Bosch process enables the large-scale production of value-added NH3, however, it is against the principle of sustainable development theory due to the high operational costs and negative environmental impacts of the Haber-Bosch process [13–15]. Hence, it is imperative to explore green and sustainable approaches to produce NH3 and simultaneously realize global environmental sustainability. Artificial electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis (which can couple with clean renewable electricity) is recently becoming a research hotspot, where the majority of researchers use N2 gas as the N source [16–19]. Although electrocatalytic N2 reduction reaction (NRR) provides an eco-friendly and sustainable route for ambient NH3 production, the conversion efficiency of N2 reduction to NH3 is unsatisfactory because of the high thermodynamic stability of the N2 molecule. Fortunately, the more active N sources (i.e., NO, NO2 −, NO3 −) but harmful to the environment have been deemed as attractive precursors to achieve effective NH3 production, and meanwhile, the development of electrocatalytic NO reduction reaction (NORR) and NO3 −/NO2 − (NO x −) reduction reaction (NtrRR) is also expected to control and mitigate the related environmental pollution [20–28]. Although many promising studies have been done in the field of artificial electrosynthesis of NH3, the design and development of active electrocatalysts with high selectivity and stability to achieve efficient NH3 production remain certain challenges. In this Account, we review recent advances in electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis (Fig. 1 ). Firstly, we introduce three electrochemical NH3 synthesis routes (NRR, NORR, and NtrRR) and then summarize recent advances in electrocatalyst development for ambient NH3 synthesis, mainly involving catalytic mechanisms, theoretical advances, and electrochemical performance. The challenges and future perspectives are also proposed in the concluding remarks, aiming to provide experience and inspire more critical insights for the electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis reactions. 2 Fundamentals of electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis Electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis provides a promising carbon-neutral and sustainable strategy to produce NH3 employing electrons as the green reductant and water as the proton source. Meanwhile, unlike CO2-emitting fossil fuels, the power input in the electrocatalytic process can be provided by renewable energy sources, such as solar, wind, and even tidal energy. Moreover, this process has great potential to achieve decentralized and on-site/-demand NH3 production, further supporting the manufacture of distributed fertilizers and thus reducing transportation costs. Nevertheless, in the electrocatalytic NRR system, the highly inert N≡N bond in N2 (activation energy of 941 kJ mol−1), the limited solubility of N2 (~0.69 mmol L−1 in water at 25 °C) [29], and the competing hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) cause extremely low conversion efficiency and NH3 yield, which is far from satisfying the practical demand. Although NO is a more active N source than N2, its solubility is still relatively poor in water (~1.94 mmol L−1 at 25 °C) [30]. Therefore, in the electrocatalytic NORR system, concentrated NO or even pure NO is required for NO electroreduction to NH3, heavily limiting its practical application. As for the electrocatalytic NtrRR system, the electrocatalysis is almost performed in simulated electrolytes, and there have been no studies on the large-scale treatment of real wastewater from different sources. Besides, even with good electrocatalytic activity under real wastewater conditions, a large amount of wastewater needs to be treated, which means large reactors and long reaction times. Hence, it is difficult to foresee whether sufficient volumes of wastewater can be supplied. Moreover, large-scale application of electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis has been limited by the lack of efficient electrocatalysts with high selectivity and low energy consumption and by the lack of research on long-term operational stability of electrode materials under practical conditions, as well as by the lack of a comprehensive techno-economic assessment. In fact, all three electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis routes (NRR, NORR, and NtrRR) are a multi-step process involving multiple electron/proton transfer and complex intermediate evolution, in which a series of reduction products would vary with the number of transferred electrons. High selectivity can be achieved when the elementary reactions and formation of various by-products are correctly understood. We exhibit here several important half-cell reactions in the following sections [31]. Some practical methods for suppressing the HER have been proven to be effective, such as adjusting the pH of electrolytes, employing K-based phosphate buffer saline, and engineering the electrode/catalyst/electrolyte interface [32,33]. In addition, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is performed on the anodic side: 4OH− →O2(g) + 4H2O(l) + 4e−, E 0 = 1.23 V vs. RHE 3 Electrocatalytic N2 reduction Electrocatalytic NRR has emerged as a potential alternative to the highly energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process for sustainable NH3 synthesis. Until now, massive excellent papers have discussed and summarized the reaction mechanisms, theoretical methods, catalyst design strategies, and ammonia detection methods in NRR [34–36]. Especially, in recent years, researchers have made significant advances in improving the NH3-production efficiency of NRR electrocatalysts [37–39]. For instance, in 2020, both Sun's [40] and Zhang's [41] groups made a comprehensive discussion on effective strategies for developing highly active NRR electrocatalysts to produce NH3. Shao and his colleagues [42] summarized the NRR performance of two-dimensional nanomaterials in 2021. Besides, our group also discussed recent progress in catalyst design strategies [43] and summarized iron-group electrocatalysts for electrochemical NRR [44]. To date, almost all aspects of NRR catalyst research have been explored. In this section, we mainly discuss the mechanisms of NRR, recent theoretical advances of NRR, and some recent NRR electrocatalysts and compare their NH3-production efficiency. 3.1 Mechanisms of NRR Currently, the proposed mechanisms of N2 reduction to NH3 include dissociative, associative, enzymatic, and Mars-van Krevelen (MvK), as shown in Fig. 2 [45,46]. In the dissociative mechanism, the N≡N bond in N2 is firstly broken up into two N-adatoms with high energy input, and the N-adatoms are successively hydrogenated to form NH3, which is well documented by the Haber-Bosch process for industrial NH3 synthesis. As for most electrochemical NRR systems, the hydrogenation process occurs before the cleavage of the N≡N bond, and the NH3 is released only after the cleavage of the final N−N bond, known as the associative mechanism. Specifically, this mechanism can be further divided into the distal and alternating pathways according to the sequence of the N atoms being hydrogenated. In the distal pathway, the N atom away from the catalytic surface is preferentially hydrogenated until the release of NH3, and then the remained N adatom undergoes further hydrogenation to produce the second NH3 molecule. However, in the alternating pathway, the two N atoms are hydrogenated alternately, until two NH3 molecules are released in turn. Additionally, the hydrogenation process of the enzymatic pathway is similar to the alternating pathway but N2 is absorbed in a side-on adsorption mode, which doesn't usually occur on heterogeneous catalysts. Recently, the MvK mechanism proposed by Skúlason and Abghoui is highly preferred by transition metal nitrides. The first NH3 molecule is derived from the hydrogenation of the surface N atoms and leaves a vacancy, which is subsequently refilled by a molecular N2. The hydrogenation of the newly available surface nitrogen atom forms the second NH3 molecule [47]. Except for the above-mentioned classical NRR pathways, A new two-step reaction pathway has been discovered in practice by in situ spectroscopies [48,49]. Specifically, Shao et al. [49] detected a N2H x (0 ≤ x ≤ 2) intermediate in the NRR process on Rh surfaces based on surface-enhanced infrared-absorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS, a N=N stretching mode at ~2020 cm−1) and differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS, a signal at m/z = 29), and further deduced a possible reaction pathway (i.e., two-step reaction pathway) (Fig. 3 ). In this pathway, the absorbed N2 molecule first reduces to N2H2* by a two-electron transfer process, followed by its desorption and further decomposition to release NH3 (N2H2 → 2NH3 + 2N2). This work provides important new insights into the NRR reaction pathway on metal surfaces and may inspire further studies on NRR mechanisms and the rational design of more advanced electrocatalysts. 3.2 Recent theoretical advances of NRR Theoretical studies based on density functional theory (DFT) are of great significance for an in-depth understanding of the mechanisms of NRR and the effective screening of novel electrocatalysts. Materials including pure transition metals, metal alloys, transition metal oxides/nitrides/carbides/bo- rides, single-atom catalysts (SACs), as well as non-metal catalysts have been widely explored for the electrochemical NRR. Early in 2012, Nørskov's group [50] screened a series of transition metals to find candidates for the NRR in acidic media, and showed that Mo, Fe, Rh, and Ru were the most active elements on the top of the volcano diagram (Fig. 4(a) ). However, they also presented high activity for the HER, resulting in the reduced Faraday efficiency (FE) of NH3. Besides, some early transition metals such as Sc, Y, Ti, and Zr were confirmed to have stronger bonding ability with N adatoms than that with H adatoms, and a significant amount of NH3 compared with H2 should be produced, even at quite negative potentials. Later, in 2017, Skúlason and co-workers [51] theoretically explored the catalytic activity of 11 transition metal dioxides for electrochemical NRR at ambient conditions (Fig. 4(b)). They found that the most promising rutile oxide candidates were ReO2 and TaO2 for NH3 electrosynthesis. NbO2 has similar strength for NNH and H adsorption so both NH3 and H2 are expected to form on NbO2. Besides, OsO2 and IrO2 were excluded as promising NRR catalysts because of their strong hydrogen adsorption. At the same time, Skúlason's group [52] investigated the possibility of transition metal nitrides for electroreduction of N2 to NH3 via the MvK mechanism (Fig. 4(c)), and they revealed that the zinc blende(100) facet of RuN, CrN, and WN were stable and active for NRR, which can be regenerated and endured the NRR cycle. Sun et al. [53] theoretically examined the NRR activity of M3C2 transition metal carbides from the d 2, d 3, and d 4 series and identified that they were promising for N2 capture and reduction. Subsequently, in 2020, Zeng's group [54] systematically investigated a series of 3d, 4d, and 5d-transition metal M2C (M = Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Zr, Nb, Mo, Ta, and Hf) MXenes as potential catalysts for NRR, and found that two newly predicted MXenes (i.e., 3d 5-Mn2C and 3d 6-Fe2C) possess the best NRR activity due to the weaker N2 capture strength with smaller Eads(*N2) than other M2C MXenes (Fig. 4(d)). Recently, Huang et al. [55] established a theoretical landscape of 16 MBenes as the NRR catalysts and identified that 7 MBenes (including CrB, MoB, WB, Mo2B, V3B4, CrMnB2, and CrFeB2) had high activity for NRR with a theoretical limiting potential of about −0.22 to −0.82 V (Fig. 4(e)) and superior selectivity due to the inhibited HER. Recently, SACs have also been proposed as a kind of promising candidates for NRR. For example, Sun et al. [56] systematically studied the catalytic role of single-boron for NRR. Among the 21 Boron-based concept NRR catalysts, single B sites supported on graphene and substituted into h-MoS2 were identified as two promising catalysts with a small energy requirement and high selectivity for NRR (Fig. 4(f)). Then, in 2023, Jiang's group [57] screened a series of single 3d transition metal atoms anchored by g-C3N4 (TM@g-C3N4) to find candidates for NRR. The results showed that V@g-C3N4 is expected to be a promising electrocatalytic material for NRR. 3.3 Advances in NRR electrocatalysts Some noble metals such as Ru [58], Au [59], Pd [60], and Ag [61] are active for NRR, but nature scarcity heavily restricts their practical applications. Hence, the research hotspot has tended to focus on noble-metal-free alternatives [62–68]. Our group explored the electrochemical N2-to-NH3 conversion ability of various non-noble metal materials, including their oxides, hydroxides, sulfides, phosphides, carbides, nitrides, and metal-organic frameworks. Besides, the NRR properties of metal-free nanomaterials have been also widely investigated by our group. Many of the NRR electrocatalysts prepared by us still can provide satisfactory NH3-production efficiency (Table 1 ), and our research findings have inspired more effective catalyst designs. Transition metal oxides (TMOs) are earth-abundant and can be easily prepared on a large scale. Our group was the first to prove that TiO2 can catalyze N2-to-NH3 conversion [69] and successfully developed a variety of effective strategies to enhance the electrocatalytic performance of TiO2, including oxygen defect engineering [70], heteroatom doping (La [71], V [72], Fe [73], Mn [74], Cu [75], B [76], and C [77]), and combing with carbon materials [78,79]. Our group detailedly investigated the enhancement mechanism of Fe-doped TiO2 [73], Mn-doped TiO2 [74], and Cu-doped TiO2 [75] at an atom scale for electrochemical NRR. DFT calculations revealed that the synergistic effect of oxygen defect and bi-Ti3+ pairs significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic NRR performance of Fe-doped TiO2 and Mn-doped TiO2. As for Cu-doped TiO2, the improved NRR performance was attributed to the synergies of three ion pairs of Cu+-Ti4+, Ti3+-Ti4+, and Ti3+-Ti3+. In addition, Zheng and co-workers adopted Zr-doping to induce bi-Ti3+ pairs in TiO2, which also enormously enhanced the catalytic ability for electrochemical N2 fixation [80]. In a theoretical study by Nguyen et al. [81], DFT calculations were performed on the hematite(0001) surface to investigate the N2-to-NH3 reduction process of Fe2O3 at an atomistic level. The results suggested that the associative mechanism seemed to favor the reaction, and the most energy-demanding step was the formation of *NNH intermediate. Park and co-workers [82] reported that the γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles can act as a NRR catalyst for NH3 electrosynthesis, presenting a yield of 12.5 nmol h−1 mgcat. −1 and a FE of 1.9%. The enhanced NRR activity can be achieved by introducing a high-conductivity substrate because the rich electronic property of the substrate appears to be favorable for electron injection into the antibonding orbital of N2 and following N2 reduction [83]. Based on this, we [84] investigated the NRR performance of Fe2O3 nanoparticle-reduced graphene oxide composite (Fe2O3-rGO), and the experimental results illustrated that Fe2O3-rGO as the NRR catalyst showed a promising NH3-production performance (22.13 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 5.89%). Chen et al. [85] also explored the positive role of catalyst substrate, and the results indicated that the specific carbon sites (at the interface between carbon nanotube and iron particles) were favorable to activating N2 molecule, which facilitates the following hydrogenation reaction. The experimental results showed that Fe2O3 nanoparticles supported on carbon nanotubes (Fe2O3-CNT) as a NRR catalyst can obtain an NH3 yield of 2.2 × 10−3 g m−2 h−1, superior to Fe2O3 (1.0 × 10−3 g m−2 h−1). Besides, Our group verified that V oxides were capable of effectively catalyzing the N2 reduction, including VO2 hollow microsphere (14.85 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 3.97%) [86] and V2O3/C (12.3 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 7.28%) [87]. Recently, the fact that β-FeOOH nanorod is active for electrochemical N2 reduction has been demonstrated by our group [88]. DFT calculations uncovered that the Fe-edge active sites of the β-FeOOH(110) surface were favorable for the activation of N2 molecule. When tested in 0.5 mol L−1 LiClO4, the β-FeOOH nanorod catalyst exhibited a peak FE of 6.7% and a maximum NH3-production rate of 23.32 μg h−1 mgcat. −1. We further confirmed the electrocatalytic activity of β-FeOOH nanorod for NRR can be significantly improved by F doping [89]. As expected, the resultant β-FeO(OH,F) catalyst presented excellent NRR performance with a satisfactory NH3 yield of 42.38 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 and an FE of up to 9.02%. Nevertheless, the electrochemical property of FeOOH is still limited owing to its unsatisfactory electrical conductivity. To solve the problem, we constructed FeOOH quantum dots on a graphene sheet (FeOOH QDs-GS) as an active NRR catalyst [90], and the as-prepared catalyst indeed greatly enhanced the NH3-production efficiency with an excellent FE of up to 14.6%. In 2018, our group [91] first theoretically and experimentally identified that 2H MoS2 can effectively catalyze N2-to-NH3 conversion. DFT calculations revealed that the positively charged Mo-edge was confirmed as the active site for N2 activation and the limiting potential was only 0.68 eV for the reductive protonation of adsorbed N2, while the basal plane was inert and even cannot effectively adsorb the N2 molecule (Fig. 5(a) and 5(b) ). The experimental results showed that the MoS2 catalyst had a good NRR performance with an NH3 yield of 8.08 × 10−11 mol s−1 cm−1 and FE of 1.17 % in neutral media. Besides, our study [92] also demonstrated that the enhanced NRR performance (29.28 µg h−1 mgcat. −1, 8.34%,) can be achieved on defect-rich 2H MoS2 nanoflower. The main reason was that the limiting potential from *NH2 to *NH3 (0.6 eV) was lower than that of pristine MoS2 (Fig. 5(c)). Our studies not only offer a promising NRR catalyst but also stimulate greater interest in MoS2 catalyst design toward activating inert basal planes and improving electronic conductivity. Huang's group [93] studied the nitrogen adsorption ability of three kinds of MoS2 (2H, 1T’, and 1T‴ MoS2) and confirmed that the best candidate for electrocatalytic NRR was 1T‴ phase. The optimal 1T″′ MoS2 exhibited a high NH3 yield of 9.09 μg h−1 mg−1, which was about twice as much as 1T’ MoS2 and nine times as much as 2H MoS2, and the FE of 13.6% achieved by 1T″′ MoS2 was also far superior to 1T’ and 2H MoS2. Remarkably, interface engineering is an effective approach to heavily improve the NRR performance of MoS2-based electrocatalysts, as the strong interfacial interactions of two species can accelerate high-speed electron transport and optimize the free energies of reactive intermediates. According to rational interface engineering, Chu and co-workers [94] reported that MoS2/C3N4 as an efficient NRR catalyst can obtain an NH3 yield of 18.5 μg h−1 mg−1 and a FE of 17.8%. To obtain further insights into the enhanced NRR activity of MoS2/C3N4, a set of potential NRR active sites in MoS2 or C3N4 alone and MoS2/C3N4 heterostructure, as well as the free energies of all intermediates on NRR-active Mo edge sites were analyzed by DFT calculations (Figs. 5(d) and 5(e)). The calculations revealed that enhanced NRR performance was mainly derived from the efficient interface coupling interaction between MoS2 and C3N4, which can effectively promote the *N2H stabilization and concurrently decrease the reaction energy barrier. Besides, based on interface engineering, Xie's group [95] developed a range of other metal sulfides supported on the N,S co-doped graphene sheet (NS-G) for electrocatalytic NRR. The successful construction of strong bridging bonds (Co-N/S-C) existed at the interface between CoS2/CoS nanoparticles and NS-G (Figs. 5(f)–5(h)) accelerated the electron transfer, which favors the electrocatalytic activity for NRR. As expected, the experimental results exhibited that the CoS2/NS-G hybrid had the best activity for electrochemical N2 fixation. Our group [96] also experimentally demonstrated that CoS2 nanoparticles-embedded N-doped carbon nanobox (CoS2@NC) as the NRR electrocatalyst can efficiently convert N2 into NH3, achieving a high yield of 17.45 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 with FE of 4.6%. Given the high electrocatalytic activity of transition metal sulfides (TMSs) toward NRR, other TMSs including CuS concave polyhedral superstructures (CuS-CPSs) and ZrS2 nanofibers with a sulfur vacancy (ZrS2 NF-Vs) were also reported as efficient NRR catalysts by our group [97,98]. Transition metal nitrides (TMNs) possess a promising application prospect for N2 electroreduction to NH3, owning to the merits of satisfactory electrical conductivity, rich N adatoms, and reliable stability [99,100]. Recent theoretical analysis [101] has identified that VN is an underlying candidate for electrochemical NRR. Yang et al. [102] experimentally proved that VN nanoparticles were active for electrocatalytic NRR to produce NH3, and further revealed that VN0.7O0.45 species on the surface was the active phase for N2-to-NH3 conversion. Additionally, our group [103] successfully synthesized VN nanoarray on Ti mesh as a self-standing electrode for NRR, exhibiting high electrochemical stability. Except for VN, other TMNs also have been prepared as NRR catalysts for ambient NH3 electrosynthesis, such as MoN nanosheets (3.01 × 10−10 mol s−1 cm−2, 1.15%) [100], MoN@NC with Mo vacancies (MV-MoN@NC, 76.9 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 6.9%) [104], Mo2N nanorod (78.4 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 4.5%) [105], graphdiyne (GDY)/Co2N nanowires (219.72 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 58.6%) [106], N-vacancy-rich 2D W2N3 nanosheets (NV-W2N3, 3.80 ± 0.32 × 10−11 mol s−1 cm−2, 11.67 ± 0.93%) [107], etc. Particularly, Li's group [106] synthesized 3D self-standing GDY/Co2N, and the catalyst showed remarkable electrocatalytic activity for NRR, creating an unprecedented FE of 58.60% with a large NH3 yield of 219.72 μg h−1 mgcat. −1 in acidic media. Moreover, it also showed a high NH3-production performance (126.66 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 35.84%) in neutral media. In the light of the theory of d orbital, transition metal carbides (TMCs) own similar adsorption capacity for electron-enriched adsorbates [108], meanwhile, the excess occupied orbitals in TMCs can afford more electrons to the π orbitals of N2, and hence weaken the N≡N bond, endowing TMCs with enormous development potential to promote electroreduction of N2 to NH3 [49,109]. Our group [110] prepared TiC/C nanofibers (TiC/C NFs) by electrospinning technique and following calcination treatment, and the as-prepared catalyst can effectively catalyze N2-to-NH3 conversion with a good NH3-production ability (14.1 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 5.8%) in acidic conditions. Besides, an outstanding NH3-producing capability (95.1 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 8.13%) was achieved on the Mo2C nanorod identified by our group [111]. In addition, other groups also paid intensive attention to developing TMCs as NRR electrocatalysts with high activity and selectivity, such as bioinspired Fe3C@C [112], Mo2C/C [113], Mo3Fe3C [114], V8C7/C [115], etc. Transition metal phosphides (TMPs) present metalloid properties and superior electrical conductivity [116], which is favorable for improving their electrochemical properties. Recent works of our group also verified the electrocatalytic activity of TMPs toward NRR, such as VP/V foil [117], CoP3 nanoneedle array [118], Cu3P nanoribbons [119], Cu3P-rGO [120], FeP2-rGO [121], etc. More importantly, we confirmed that alkylthiol surface engineering is indeed a successful strategy to improve the NRR performance of electrocatalysts. Specifically, we constructed [122] a hydrophobic self-assembled monolayer (h-SAM) of octadecanethiol (C18) on Fe3P nanoarrays (C18@Fe3P), which can inhibit the HER by water repelling but permit the flow of non-polar N2 gas to the Fe3P surface, thus boosting the N2-to-NH3 conversion process (Figs. 6(a)–6(c) ). The catalyst achieved an improved NH3-production performance in neutral media (1.80 × 10−10 mol s−1 cm−2, 11.22%). Furthermore, the C18@CoP nanoarray as an active NRR electrocatalyst was also prepared by our group [123]. DFT calculations revealed that the C18-thiol decorated CoP(211) surface became more active and further facilitated the electroreduction of N2 to NH3 (Figs. 6(d) and 6(e)). As expected, the C18@CoP catalyst achieved superior NRR performance compared to the CoP counterpart (Fig. 6(f)). In addition, our recent work suggested that the P content would influence the electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst toward NRR [118]. We prepared cobalt phosphide with different P content (i.e., CoP3, CoP2, CoP) as NRR electrocatalysts and the experimental results displayed that the increase of P content contributed to a higher NH3 yield. First-principles calculations unveiled that CoP3 had the lowest reaction energy barrier and can effectively promote N2 reduction to NH3. Therefore, it is necessary to ascertain the optimal ratio of metal to phosphorus for achieving more efficient N2-to-NH3 conversion on TMPs. Recent research verified that high-curvature structures (such as sharp spikes) can amplify the local electric fields and may increase the ion concentration near the nanospikes [124]. Besides, materials with such special structures can expose sufficient active sites, which contributes to improving the relevant electrocatalytic ability. Consequently, it may be an effective strategy to rationally design catalysts with high-curvature structures for enhanced NRR performance. Our group successfully designed a class of catalysts with abundant-oriented nanospike structures, such as Bi nanodendrites [125], dendritic Cu [126], and Sn dendrite [127], which were active for electrochemical converting N2 into NH3 under ambient conditions. Another category of materials extensively employed in electrochemical NRR research is the metal-organic frameworks (MOF) and their derivatives, which were effective for N2-to-NH3 conversion [66,128–130]. Improving the utilization efficiency of catalysts is of crucial importance for cutting down production costs and promoting sustainable development, so it is highly desired to design and develop catalysts with smaller sizes. Single-atom catalysts (screened) have drawn special research attention and emerged as alluring candidates in heterogeneous catalytic reactions, attributing to their maximized atom-utilization efficiency and excellent catalytic activity [131,132]. To date, many SACs have been developed as NRR electrocatalysts for ambient NH3 production, such as SA-Mo/NPC (34.0 ± 3.6 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 14.6 ± 1.6%) [133], FeSA-N-C (7.48 μg h−1 mg−1, 56.55%) [134], NC-Cu SA (53.3 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 13.8%) [135], Y1/NC (21.8 μg cm−1 h−1, 12.1%) and Sc1/NC (19.2 μg cm−1 h−1, 11.2%) [136], W-NO/NC (12.62 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 8.35%) [137], etc. Despite the fast development of SACs in catalysis science, there are still some challenges in the current research to meet the demand for practical applications of SACs. Achieving the facile synthesis and improving the metal loading content are two crucial challenges in the field of SACs synthesis. Furthermore, accurately regulating the coordination environment of metal atoms is indispensable for enhancing the catalytic property of SACs. In addition, a precise understanding of the structure-performance relationship and catalytic mechanism of SACs-based catalysts depends on in situ characterization technologies and theoretical calculations. By effectively addressing the above-mentioned challenges, it is prospective to rationally design specific catalysts for NRR, achieving improved NH3-production performance. In contrast with the above NRR catalysts, metal-free materials feature many advantages, including lower price, environmental friendliness (avoiding metal ion release during the catalytic process), and weak hydrogen adsorption, which makes them have the potential to electrocatalytic N2 reduction to NH3. Generally, carbon-based materials possess large surface area and high electrical conductivity, which would facilitate electrochemical N2 fixation. However, pristine carbon-based materials show limited catalytic performance because the π electrons in carbon-based materials are too inert [49]. Heteroatoms doping and vacancy engineering can induce more active sites by tailoring the electronic structure of carbon-based materials, contributing to enhanced electrochemical performance. We and other researchers reported that N-doped nanoporous carbon membranes (NCMs) [138], O-doped graphene (O-G) [139], O-doped carbon nanosheet (O-CN) [140], B-doped graphene (BG) [141], P-doped graphene (PG) [142], S-doped graphene (S-G) [143], S-doped carbon nanosphere (S-CNS) [144], defect-rich fluorographene nanosheets (d-FG) [145], defect-rich commercial carbon cloth (CC) [146], etc. were capable of effectively boosting N2-to-NH3 conversion. In addition, other metal-free materials reported by our group were also highly active for NRR, such as boron phosphide (BP) [147], boron nanosheet (BNS) [148], B4C nanosheet [149], and hexagonal boron nitride nanosheet (h-BNNS) [150]. These reports forcefully confirmed that metal-free materials can serve as efficient NRR catalysts for artificial NH3 electrosynthesis. As discussed above, we summarized the recent advances in NRR electrocatalyst development for ambient NH3 production. The reported studies and corresponding NH3-production efficiency of electrocatalysts are generalized in Table 1. Electrochemical NRR is indeed an alluring pathway to realize ambient NH3 electrosynthesis, however, to achieve economical, eco-friendly, and sustainable N2-to-NH3 conversion at a more practical level, future research works should be considered: (1) Suppressing HER. Electrochemical NRR is always concomitant with competitive HER in aqueous electrolytes, which results in limited selectivity for electrocatalytic N2-to-NH3 conversion. Accordingly, it is imperative to take some HER-retarding strategies to resolve the selectivity issue toward NH3 formation. For instance, constructing a hydrophobic interface through water-soluble H+-repelling molecules and adding organic additives in the electrolytes are both viable strategies to suppress HER. Additionally, the adsorption energies of *N2 and *H can be predicted in advance by DFT calculations, which is beneficial to rapidly single out the effective catalysts, greatly reducing the experimental costs. (2) Ensure the accuracy of the NRR results. The NH3 yield produced from electrochemical NRR is usually rather small, so, to guarantee the produced NH3 indeed attributing to the NRR process, eliminating possible N-containing contaminations from the electrolysis cell, electrocatalyst, electrolyte, and feed gas is highly necessary. (3) Advanced in situ electrochemical characterizations for NRR are critical. Directly observing the transformations of reactive intermediates by in situ characterization techniques facilitates to better obtain a deeper understanding of NRR pathways. 4 Electrocatalytic NO reduction NO is an essential intermediate in nitrogen transformation reactions, however, the accelerated emission of NO by human activities has seriously unbalanced nature's N-cycle and ineluctably causes severe environmental issues, which will heavily imperil all living systems [10,151]. Therefore, developing effective and green NO control technology is highly desired. Electrocatalytic NORR operated in ambient conditions offers a promising and sustainable route for NO abatement and even added-value NH3 production [152–154]. To realize more cost-effective NO-to-NH3 conversion, many research efforts focus on catalyst design for electrochemical NORR. In this section, we discuss the mechanisms of NORR, recent theoretical advances of NORR, and some recent electrocatalysts for NORR. 4.1 Mechanisms of NORR According to the adsorption patterns of NO molecules on the catalyst surface, the electrocatalytic NO reduction to NH3 may follow different reaction routes, including N-end, O-end, and side-on (Fig. 7 ) [155]. In principle, the electrocatalytic NORR can follow a dissociative or associative mechanism. In the dissociative mechanism, the N−O bond is first broken up on the active site, and then the resulting N* and O* will be hydrogenated separately. In the associative mechanism, the adsorbed NO molecules are firstly hydrogenated to form H x NOH y intermediates and continually undergo stepwise hydrogenation to release NH3 and H2O. During the electrochemical NO-to-NH3 process, the hydrogenation of the adsorbed atom proceeds via either a Tafel or a Heyrovsky-type route. Specifically, in the Tafel-type route, the solvated protons firstly adsorb on the catalyst surface forming adsorbed H*, followed by surface hydrogenation. While the adsorbed NO and intermediate species are hydrogenated directly in the Heyrovsky-type route. Consequently, the NORR mechanisms are further divided into four categories based on the type of hydrogenation, including Tafel-dissociative (T-D), Tafel-associative (T-A), Heyrovsky-dissociative (H-D), and Heyrovsky-associative (H-A) mechanisms. Moreover, the T-A and H-A are further assigned to four specific routes depending on the type of adsorption associated with the respective pathways, named distal-O, distal-N, alternating-O, and alternating-N, respectively [153]. 4.2 Recent theoretical advances of NORR In 2020, Xiao and co-workers [153] systematically screened 10 transition metals based on DFT calculations to find promising catalysts for NORR. The comparison of the ΔG-determining steps between NORR, NRR, and HER is shown in Fig. 8(a) . The result exhibited that NO reduction was more thermodynamically feasible than NRR and HER, indicating NORR was more active and selective than NRR. Besides, Cu was predicted as the most active transition metal for NORR, as the catalytic activity over Cu is very close to the activity optimum (Fig. 8(b)). Kinetic barrier calculations further displayed that NH3 was the preferred product on the Cu(111) surface during the electrocatalytic NORR process, compared to H2, N2, and N2O (Fig. 8(c)). Subsequently, Rossmeisl et al. [156] also theoretically predicted that Cu was the most promising catalyst for NORR, and the potential limiting step was identified as the first hydrogenation of *NO. In 2021, Xiao's group [157] screened a series of M2B2 type MBenes from the IVB to V transition metals and systematically explored the activity and selectivity for NORR. The theoretical results showed that Fe2B2, Mn2B2, and Rh2B2 can act as promising electrocatalysts for NO-to-NH3 conversion with smaller limiting potentials than other MBenes. Recently, Yu et al. [158] systematically investigated the NORR performance of 29 transition-metal atoms embedded on the N-doped BP monolayer (MN3/BP) using first-principles calculations, and MoN3/BP and IrN3/BP SACs were screened out as promising NORR electrocatalysts for NH3 production. Ma and co-workers [159] first proposed the metal-free catalyst (i.e., P doped single-layer C2N) for direct electroreduction of NO to NH3, and theoretically investigated its electronic and catalytic properties. They found that the double P doped C2N showed high activity and selectivity for NORR, which is associated with the sp 3 hybridization of the P atom. Later, in 2022, Zhou et al. [160] theoretically explored the potential of hBN-graphene heterostructures with modified interface as metal-free NORR electrocatalysts. The results showed the introduction of Ccenter-CN2 configuration endowed the modified hBN-graphene interface with remarkable NORR catalytic activity. Moreover, a series of 2D materials (such as graphene, g-CN, g-BC, C3N4, BN, etc.) obtained improved catalytic activity for NORR when the Ccenter-CN2 configuration was introduced. These theoretical findings provide us with feasible research directions for NORR catalyst design. 4.3 Advances in NORR electrocatalysts Most noble metals show encouraging NORR activity, and many such catalysts produce NH3 as the primary reduction product [161–163]. Whereas, their scarcity heavily restricts the widespread applications. Electrochemical NORR catalyzed by lower-cost materials remains a challenging but extremely valuable work. At present, our group and others have made many efforts in developing NORR electrocatalysts with advantages of high catalytic activity and low prices based on non-noble metals, such as Cu [153], NiO [154], MoS2 [164], Fe2O3 nanorods [165], CoSe2@CNTs (CNTs = carbon nanotubes) [166], etc. Moreover, recent noble-metal-free electrocatalysts for NORR are listed in Table 2 . Recently, Xiao's group [153] theoretically predicted that Cu was the most promising catalyst for electrocatalytic NORR to NH3. Further, the experimental results confirmed the superior catalytic activity of the Cu foam (CF) electrode for converting NO to NH3. The catalyst obtained a maximum FE of 93.5% with a satisfactory NH3 yield of 517.1 μmol cm−2 h −1 but hardly any NH3 was formed during the NRR process, indicating the competitiveness of NORR over NRR on the Cu surface (Figs. 9(a) and 9(b) ). Besides, the activity of Cu foam for NORR can maintain 100 h (Fig. 9(c)) and all the characterizations (as shown in Figs. 9(d)–9(f)) indicated that the Cu foam was robust enough after 100-h stability test. Later, Chen et al. [167] used the chemical reduction method for uniform decoration of ultrasmall Cu nanoparticles onto the porous TiO2, and the as-prepared catalyst exhibited a high NH3 yield of 3520.80 μg h −1 mg−1 with a FE of 86.49%. The improved surface area and porous channels of the catalyst improved the adsorption of NO, leading to efficient NH3 production. Although NO is a more active N source than N2, the solubility of NO in aqueous electrolytes is still relatively poor, so concentrated NO was required for NO electroreduction, heavily hindering its further development. The use of EDTA-Fe2+ metal complex (EFeMC) is an effective method for rapid NO capture, resulting in increased NO solubility in an electrolyte. Kwon et al. [168] achieved the selective electroreduction of NO to NH3 (with nearly 100% NH3 FE) on a nanostructured silver electrode by using an EFeMC-designed electrolyte. Noticeably, A low concentration of NO gas (1%) was employed in this work for NO electroreduction, and they claimed that NO first adsorbed on the metal complex to form NO@EFeMC species, and it subsequently involved in the electron transfer process to produce NH3 along with the regeneration of EFeMC (Fig. 10(a) ). Besides, the authors estimated the economy of the system (Fig. 10(b)), and the result suggested NH3 production cost via NORR in the EFeMC-designed electrolyte is 2.5 times higher than the commercial price of NH3 but can be market competitive with an electricity price of $0.03 kWh−1 and with a current density of > 125 mA cm−2. Constructing a gas diffusion electrode (GDE) has been also recognized as a great method to improve the mass transport rate of insoluble reactants [169]. Han's group [170] developed a Fe/carbon black-incorporated GDE cell for diluted NO electroreduction to NH3 (Fig. 11(a) ). The experimental results suggested that the mass transport rate of NO can be highly enhanced through the GDE-based system, and the high FEs in the GDE cell (using 1% NO) were obtained at the lower potential window (Fig. 11(b)). Besides, Jiao and co-workers [171] investigated some representative transition metals (i.e., Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Pd, Ag, and Pt) for the electroreduction of NO and N2O in a gas-fed electrolyzer. High current densities for electrochemical NO reduction and N2O reduction were observed on all metal catalysts. Cu exhibited the highest NH3 selectivity for NO electroreduction (Fig. 11(c)), which accords well with findings by Xiao's group [153]. For electrocatalytic N2O reduction, the N2 molecule was the only available N-contained product and a significantly high N2 selectivity was obtained on the Co, Cu, and Ag metal catalysts (Fig. 11(d)). Furthermore, the experimental results of the NO partial pressure test unveiled that the single-N products and N-N coupled products were favored at high and low NO coverage, respectively. (Figs. 11(e) and 11(f)). Bi metal possesses limited HER activity due to its weak binding with H adatoms [172], and thus it would be an attractive material for the electroreduction of NO to NH3. Our group [173] demonstrated that Bi nanodendrites (Bi NDs) with sharp spikes (Fig. 12(a) ) can serve as a high-active NORR catalyst for ambient NH3 electrosynthesis. The Bi NDs electrocatalyst displayed admirable NH3-production performance (1194 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 89.2%) (Fig. 12(b)) in neutral electrolyte containing Fe(II)EDTA. DFT calculations revealed that NO was inclined to bind with the bridge site on the Bi(012) surface through the N atom, and the binding was much stronger than that of the H atom (−0.15 vs. 0.78 eV), which should be a potential factor for the high NH3 FE. Besides, a Bi NDs-based Zn-NO battery was employed for discharging tests and can deliver a maximum power density of 2.33 mW cm−2 (Fig. 12(c)). Further, the enhanced NH3-production performance can be achieved by a composite of Bi nanoparticles and carbon nanosheets (Bi@C) (Fig. 12(d)), which has been confirmed by our group [174]. The Bi@C catalyst possessed superior electrocatalytic activity compared with the pure Bi catalyst, as evidenced by the remarkable current density gap observed for Bi@C (Fig. 12(e)). Meantime, such a catalyst exhibited outstanding NH3-generation performance (1592.5 μg h−1 mgcat. −1, 93%) in neutral media (Fig. 12(f)). Apart from Bi nanomaterials, our group is also devoted to developing other earth-abundant non-noble metal materials (peculiarly transition metal oxides, phosphides, and sulfides) for NO electroreduction to NH3. We first reported [154] that Ti mesh-supported NiO nanoarray (NiO/TM) as a NORR electrocatalyst can effectively boost NO-to-NH3 transformation, achieving a peak FE of up to 90%. Theoretical calculations manifested that the adsorption of *NO on the NiO(200) surface was much stronger than *H (−0.02 eV vs. 1.41 eV), which contributes to the high selectivity for NO electroreduction to NH3. Besides, a NiO-based Zn-NO battery can achieve a maximum power density of 0.88 mW cm−2. In another work [165], we prepared Fe2O3 nanorods to serve as a highly selective and robust NORR catalyst for NH3 electrosynthesis in neutral electrolyte containing Fe(II)EDTA absorber. Such a catalyst presented admirable catalytic activity for electrochemical NORR and achieved a satisfactory NO-to-NH3 conversion efficiency with a peak FE of 86.73% (Fig. 13(a) ). DFT calculations results further unveiled that the Fe2O3(104) surface had the highest NORR activity among the three investigated surfaces, and the strongest bonding between NO and the Fe2O3(104) surface can be deduced from the integrated crystal orbital Hamilton populations results (Fig. 13(b)). Mn-based oxides owing to their eco-friendliness and cheapness also have been studied for NO electroreduction in our work. Specifically, we successfully prepared the MnO2 nanowire array and defective MnO2−x with oxygen vacancies nanowire array (both supported on Ti mesh) as active NORR electrocatalysts for ambient NH3 production [175]. Theoretical calculations disclosed that the drastically improved NORR activity of defective MnO2−x attributed to the moderate adsorption of NO on the MnO2−x (211) surface, and all reduction steps on the MnO2−x (211) surface were exothermic processes (Fig. 13(c)). As expected, the MnO2−x catalyst had higher selectivity for NH3 production during the NORR process, compared with the MnO2 catalyst (NH3 FE: 82.8% vs. 44.8%) (Fig. 13(d)). Recently, we [176] also fabricated oxygen-defective TiO2 nanoarray supported on Ti plate (TiO2−x /TP) as an efficient electrocatalyst for NORR. An outstanding catalytic activity and NH3-production performance of TiO2−x /TP (460.1 μg h−1 cm−2, 92.5%) were achieved, much superior to the pristine TiO/TP (337.5 μg h−1 cm−2, 48.7%) (Fig. 13(e)). DFT studies indicated that the oxygen defects in TiO2−x have a positive influence on boosting the adsorption/conversion of intermediates, and the maximum energy barrier of all elementary steps of NORR on TiO2−x (0.7 eV) is much lower than that on pristine TiO2 (1.2 eV), resulting in improved NORR performance (Fig. 13(f)). Besides, He and co-workers [177] found that the existence of oxygen vacancies (especially when metals are doped with oxygen vacancies) can greatly facilitate the activation of NO. DFT calculations further indicated that La-doped-CeO2(111) with the lowest formation energy was more likely to synthesize, and adsorption energy of NO was significantly reduced on La-doped CeO2(111) surface with oxygen vacancies (La-CeO2(111)-OV). Noteworthily, all the conversion steps on La-CeO2(111)-OV for NORR were thermodynamically spontaneous processes, showing excellent activity for NH3 synthesis. More efficient electrocatalysts are thus expected to be further developed based on defect engineering strategy for improved NORR performance. TMPs with admirable electronic conductivity should also have great potential for electrochemical NO-to-NH3 conversion because numerous TMPs are known to produce value-added NH3 via NRR [117–123]. Our group first validated [178] that the Ni2P nanosheet array acting as a self-supported electrode is active to convert NO into NH3, and the catalyst achieved a peak FE of 76.9% at only −0.2 VRHE. DFT calculations manifested that the formation of NH3 was favorable on the Ni2P(111) surface, well mating with the experimental results. A CoP nanoneedle array was also prepared as a cost-effective NORR catalyst for ambient NH3 electrosynthesis [179]. Such a catalyst showed extremely high catalytic activity for NORR with an early-onset potential of −0.012 VRHE. Theoretical calculations revealed that the CoP(011P) face possessed the highest NORR activity with a low energy barrier (0.34 eV) of the first protonation step compared to other crystal planes, which would provide important guidance for CoP catalyst design for highly effective NH3 production. Meanwhile, we reported an FeP nanorod array acting as a more promising candidate for electrochemical NO-to-NH3 conversion [180]. The designed FeP catalyst exhibited excellent NORR activity, as proven by the dramatically increased current density in NO-saturated electrolyte, and achieved admirable NH3-production performance in neutral electrolyte even without adding absorbers (85.62 μmol h−1 cm−1, 88.49%). DFT calculations disclosed that the FeP(202) surface can markedly boost the activation and reduction of NO, and the potential determining step (PDS) was confirmed as the hydrogenation of *NH2 to *NH3. These works not only powerfully verify the high catalytic activity of TMP-based catalysts for NORR, but would inspire more efficient design and construction of TMP-based catalysts for electrochemical NO-to-NH3 conversion. Apart from TMPs, the electrocatalytic NORR process on TMSs was also investigated by our group. We demonstrated [164] that MoS2 nanosheet as a NORR catalyst can achieve a peak FE of 76.6% only at 0.1 VRHE, and the highest NH3 yield was 99.6 μmol h−1 cm−1 obtained at −0.7 VRHE in acidic electrolyte containing iron (II) sodium benzoate (FeIISB) absorbers (Fig. 14(a) ). Meanwhile, a rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) system was used to compare the electrocatalytic behaviors of MoS2 and Pt (Fig. 14(b)). Besides, a MoS2-based Zn-NO battery system can produce electricity and simultaneously obtain value-added NH3, offering a high power density of 1.04 mW cm−2 and an admirable NH3 yield of 411.8 μg h−1 mgcat. −1. The conversion of *NH2 to *NH3 was recognized as the PDS on the MoS2(101) surface (Fig. 14(c)). To further enhance the electrocatalytic activity toward NORR of MoS2, Chu's group [181] designed atomically Fe-doped and S-vacancy-rich MoS2 (Fe1/MoS2−x ) as a highly active NORR electrocatalyst, exhibiting a large NH3 yield of 288.2 μmol h−1 cm−1 with a FE of 82.5%, which substantially outperforms the counterparts of MoS2 and MoS2−x . DFT calculations revealed that the cooperative effect of Fe-doping and Vs facilitated the NO adsorption and activation on Fe-Mo dual sites. Meanwhile, their group [182] also designed atomically dispersed Co anchored on MoS2 (Co1/MoS2) for NO electroreduction to NH3, and the Co1/MoS2 catalyst delivered an outstanding NH3-production performance (217.6 μmol h−1 cm−1, 87.7%), significantly surpassing the pristine MoS2 (Fig. 14(d)). X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analysis confirmed the atomic level dispersion of Co atoms and Co1 was coordinated with three surface S atoms of MoS2 to form Co1-S3 moiety (Figs. 14(e)–14(g)), which was predicted to be the active site for NO reduction. Theoretical investigations manifested that Co-S3 moieties can selectively activate NO and accelerate the hydrogenation energetics, resulting in the improved NORR performance of Co1/MoS2 (Fig. 14(h)). Apart from MoS2, our group also confirmed that the S-vacancy-rich CoS nanosheet (CoS1−x ) was active for selective NO reduction to NH3 [183]. DFT calculations demonstrated that the energy barrier of the PDS on CoS1−x (100) was far below CoS(100) (0.19 vs. 0.42 eV), which may be ascribed to the localization of electrons around the sulfur vacancies (Fig. 14(i)), facilitating the activation of NO. Notably, when operated in the same test conditions, the CoS1−x catalyst had a higher current density than the pristine CoS catalyst, and the remarkable current density gap can be observed on the CoS1−x catalyst, implying the introduction of sulfur vacancies is indeed favorable for the electrochemical NORR process. Consequently, the CoS1−x catalyst displayed an NH3 yield of 44.67 μmol h−1 cm−1 with a FE of 53.62%, superior to the pristine CoS (27.02 μmol h−1 cm−1, 36.68%) (Fig. 14(j)). More in-depth characterizations of TMSs and their composites are expected in future studies to deepen the comprehension of reaction mechanisms during the electrocatalytic NORR process. Current studies for NO electrolysis are almost focused on metal-containing materials, while metal-free materials have rarely been investigated. Indeed, the development of metal-free NORR catalysts for effective NH3 production is highly desirable since metal-free materials possess the merits of low cost and environmental friendliness. Recently, our group experimentally and theoretically demonstrated [184] that honeycomb carbon nanofiber (HCNF) synthesized by electrospinning technology as a metal-free electrocatalyst was favorable to improving NORR performance. The catalyst achieved a peak FE of 88.33%, which was far superior to the counterpart of solid carbon nanofiber (33.09%) (Fig. 15(a) ). During the electrocatalytic NORR process, the NO gas can be effectively entrapped in the the interconnected nanocavities of the HCNF, and further theoretical calculations disclosed that the −OH group was the best active center for NO reduction with low energy input. Later, Li et al. [185] reported that metal-free g-C3N4 nanosheets deposited onto carbon paper (CNNS/CP) also exhibited admirable NORR performance. Moreover, the regulation of the electrode surface microenvironment through hydrophobic treatment was found to be beneficial for the improved gas-liquid-solid triphasic interface (Figs. 15(b) and 15(c)), thus favoring to enhance NO mass transfer and finally resulting in 2 times enhancement in the NH3 production. In addition, amorphous B2.6C (a-B2.6C) was identified by our group as a promising candidate for NO electroreduction, which has never been reported [20]. The experimental results exhibited that the NH3-production performance of a-B2.6C/Ti was far better than TiO2/Ti and pure Ti plate, but was inferior to a-B2.6C@TiO2/Ti (Fig. 15(d)), suggesting that the a-B2.6C was the active species during the electrocatalytic NORR process. Theoretical calculations further unveiled the catalytic mechanisms on the a-B2.6C@TiO2(101) surface for NO reduction (Fig. 15(e)). These explorations open new perspectives for the design and development of high-performance NORR electrocatalysts based on metal-free materials. Massive exhaust gases containing NO were emitted from the combustion of fuels in factories and vehicles, causing serious environmental pollution. Once emitted, NO would be speedily oxidized and converted to NO2 through the photochemical process, which further exacerbates the greenhouse effect. Therefore, the direct electroreduction of NO to value-added NH3 is an eco-friendly and promising strategy, especially when combined with renewable electricity. Practical NO concentration in real-world exhaust gases is generally low, whereas previous works on electrochemical NORR mostly focused on high-concentration NO. Here, future studies are recommended to explore advanced NORR electrocatalysts at low-concentration NO or even real exhaust gases. 5 Electrochemical reduction of nitrogen oxyanions NO3 − is essential N-species in various nitrogen transformation reactions and have considerable impacts on globe N-cycle. However, the surge of NO3 −/NO2 − contaminants (most NO3 − and NO2 − exist in aquatic ecosystems as a mixture) caused by anthropogenic activities has a major threat to the water environment and human health, which even results in global N-cycle imbalance. Fortunately, electrochemically converting hazardous NO x − into value-added NH3 provides a green pathway to achieve wastewater treatment and NH3 electrosynthesis. Thus, the NO x −-to-NH3 conversion has sparked considerable research interest, and numerous papers have been published in this field. In this context, we recommend some recent publications reported by Choi's group [186], Koper's group [187], and Zhang's group [23,188,189]. The fundamentals of NtrRR, including the research background and significance in the field, catalytic mechanisms, and recent advances in catalyst design, have been systematically elaborated in the above-recommended review papers. In this section, we focus on discussing the mechanisms of NtrRR, electrochemical in situ characterizations, and DFT calculations for NtrRR, as well as recent NtrRR electrocatalysts and comparing their NH3-production efficiency (Table 3 ). 5.1 Mechanisms of NtrRR There are two different pathways for NO3 − electroreduction, including indirect autocatalytic reduction and direct electrocatalytic reduction pathways [190–192]. Specifically, a high acidity (pH < 0) and a high concentration of NO3 − (> 1 mol L−1) prefer the indirect autocatalytic reduction of NO3 −, in which NO3 − does not partake in the electron transfer. The latter is involved in the electron-transfer process operated at a low concentration of NO3 − (< 1 mol L−1) and is discussed mainly in this section. As depicted in Fig. 16 , the detailed reaction roadmap of direct electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction is described. The first step is the adsorption of NO3 − on electrocatalyst surfaces and then the formed NO3 − (ads) is further reduced to the NO2 − (ads) with two electrons and two protons transferred, which is commonly considered a rate-determining step. The next step is the generated NO2 − (ads) reduces to NO(ads), which is a crucial intermediate as a branch to form N2 or NH3. When NO(ads) reacts with the dissolved NO (NOaq), the N2O(ads) intermediate can be formed and further reduces to N2 [193]. In terms of the pathway to NH3, the NO(ads) is first reduced to HNO(ads), followed by further reduced to H2NO(ads). Next, the H2NO(ads) is reduced to NH2OH(ads), which finally reduces to NH3 [194]. 5.2 Electrochemical in situ characterizations and DFT calculations for NtrRR Electrochemical in situ characterizations performed under real-time reaction conditions can effectively monitor the intermediates of reactants and the dynamic structure of electrocatalysts. Thus, the overall reaction pathway of electrocatalytic NO3 −RR on one specific material can be determined. Electrochemical in situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) is often employed for detecting volatile intermediates/products formed during the electrocatalytic NO3 −RR process. Electrochemical in situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) is frequently used to identify the intermediates adsorbed on the surface of the electrocatalysts. When the electrochemical online DEMS and in situ ATR-SEIRAS are employed together, it contributes to better revealing the most probable pathway of the reaction. For instance, the reaction pathway of NO3-RR on Cu-Ni dual-single-atom catalyst anchored in N-doped carbon (Cu/Ni-NC) was revealed by the electrochemical online DEMS and electrochemical in situ ATR-SEIRAS [195], as depicted in Figs. 17(a) and 17(b). The m/z signals of 17, 30, and 46 could be assigned to the NH3, NO, and NO2, respectively. Furthermore, the adsorbed intermediates on the catalyst surface were captured and monitored by in situ ATR-SEIRAS. The signals observed at 1646, 3400, and 3478 cm−1 were assigned to NH2* intermediates. The peaks at 1515 and 3353 cm−1 were ascribed to NH*. And the bands at 1110 and 1225 cm−1 were attributed to SO4 2−* and NO2*, respectively. Additionally, the peaks intensities of NH3* (1541 and 1741 cm−1) were gradually increasing with the raising of the applied potentials. Based on the detection of intermediates by online DEMS and in situ ATR-SEIRAS, they deduced the probable reaction pathway. Apart from the above-mentioned two in situ characterizations, the electrochemical in situ Raman spectroscopy can also provide sufficient evidence for the reaction pathway. As exhibited in Fig. 17(c) , the peak at 1335 cm−1 was assigned to the N=O stretching of NO2 −, indicating that NO2 − is the key intermediate species for electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction. Besides, the peaks assigned to the NO3 − and NH2 were also observed on the Fe2O3 catalyst [196]. In addition, in situ Raman can also identify the composition of electrode materials under electrochemical conditions. As shown in Fig. 17(d), Zhang's group [197] applied in situ Raman to unveil that the CuO was electrochemically reduced to Cu/Cu2O heterostructure, reflecting the real active species responsible for NO3 − electroreduction. An electrochemical online DEMS was further employed to deduce the reaction pathways. The signals of NH3, NH2OH, NO, and NO2 were observed. Combined with previous reports, a probable pathway for the electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3 (i.e., NO3* → NO2* → NO* → NOH* → NH2OH* → NH3*) was proposed. Electrochemical in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) is also an advanced tool to distinguish the active species of catalysts under electrochemical reaction conditions. Recently, Sargent et al. [198] reported Cu50Ni50 alloy as an active NO3 −RR electrocatalyst and applied operando XAS to study the electronic structure of the CuNi alloy catalysts under electrocatalytic NO3 −RR conditions. The Cu50Ni50 catalyst at different applied potentials showed a pure metallic feature in both Ni and Cu K-edge spectra (Figs. 18(a)–18(d) ). In addition, the calculated operando coordination numbers of the metal-metal bonds stayed above 11.5 at every applied potential, suggesting that the subsurface oxygen species played a minor role in the reduction process. To further understand the catalytic enhancement mechanism, ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) was employed since it can reflect the d-band center position of the catalysts. The result presented in Fig. 18(e) indicated that increasing the content of Ni in the CuNi alloy caused a promotion of the d-band center to the Fermi level, leading to a decreased antibonding occupation and stronger adsorption bonding. In recent years, DFT calculations are widely employed in different catalytic systems to predict catalysts with high activity or better understand the interaction between the active site in the catalyst and the reaction intermediates [199]. How do the prepared electrocatalysts improve the catalytic performance of NO3 − electroreduction? Most papers give a reasonable answer to this question via DFT calculations, and based on the papers, we can find that the formation of *NO3H or *HNO or *NH3 may be identified as the PDS on different electrocatalysts during electrochemical NO3 −-to-NH3 process [200–203]. The energy barrier of PDS can be reduced and the HER activity can be effectively suppressed by rational design of electrocatalysts, which can improve the catalytic performance of NO3 − electroreduction. For instance, as shown in Fig. 19 , the Gibbs free energies of NO3 −RR and HER over the Ru@C3N4/Cu and C3N4/Cu samples were calculated [200]. The hydrogenation of *NO2 to *NO2H identified as the PDS on C3N4/Cu needs a high energy barrier of 0.9 eV, but the process on Ru@C3N4/Cu was an exothermic reaction. Besides, the energy barrier of PDS on Ru@C3N4/Cu (*NO to *HNO, 0.02 eV) was significantly smaller than the ΔG PDS of C3N4/Cu. Additionally, the energy barrier of H2 formation on Ru@C3N4/Cu was much higher than that of C3N4/Cu (0.42 eV vs. 0.06 eV), suggesting the HER was effectively inhibited on Ru@C3N4/Cu. Overall, the Ru/Cu dual-sites electrocatalyst can efficiently enhance NO3 −RR performance. Similar results are also obtained on the Ru NCs/TiO2 electrocatalyst [204]. Compared with other catalysts, the Ru NCs/TiO2 catalyst favors the reaction pathway with the suppressed HER competition. The hydrogenation of *NO to *NHO on the catalysts was identified as the PDS, and the ΔG PDS of Ru NCs/TiO2 (0.18 eV) was smaller than Ru NPs/TiO2 (0.43 eV) and Ru(001) (0.52 eV). A lower energy barrier of the PDS on Ru NCs/TiO2 would be favorable for NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion. Hence, the Ru NCs/TiO2 catalyst possesses better catalytic performance because of the favorable reaction pathway. 5.3 Advances in NtrRR electrocatalysts Metallic Co has high catalytic activity for electrochemical NO3 −RR, and considerable effort has been put into developing various Co-based catalysts [205–207]. Singh's group [208] theoretically and experimentally investigated the catalytic activity of various transition metals (including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) toward electrochemically converting NO3 − into NH3, and determined that Co possessed the highest NO3 −RR activity. Especially, oxide-derived Co (denoted as OD-Co) as a catalyst applied for electrochemical NO3 −RR showed superb catalytic performance with a peak FE of 92.37 ± 6.7% and a significant current density of ~565 mA cm−2 for NH3 production at −0.8 VRHE. Moreover, the authors then integrated OD-Co as the cathode into a photovoltaic (PV)-electrolyzer cell and the system achieved a surprising solar-to-fuel efficiency of ~11% for NH3 electrosynthesis, which provides significant guidance for solar-driven NH3 synthesis via NO3 −RR. Our group demonstrated [209] that a Co-NCNT (NCNT = N-doped carbon nanotube) hybrid (Fig. 20(a) ) loaded on carbon paper (Co-NCNT/CP) as a cost-effective catalyst was active for electrochemical NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion. The catalyst presented good NH3-production ability (5996 μg h−1 cm−2, 92%) in alkaline media, superior to the counterparts of Co particle/CP and bare CP. Theoretical calculations were performed on three different Co surfaces (i.e., Co(111), Co(200), and Co(220)), revealing that Co(111) appears to be the highest active surface for NO3 − electroreduction. Besides, we also reported that Co@NC nanospheres as the NO3 −RR electrocatalyst achieved improved NH3-generation performance with an NH3 yield of 758.0 μmol h−1 mgcat. −1 and a peak FE of 96.5%. [210]. Using conductive carbon as the support to load metal nanoparticles can effectively prevent the active nanoparticles from aggregation, and simultaneously enhance the overall conductivity, which greatly facilitates the electrochemical performance of catalysts. Biomass-derived carbon with merits of abundance, cheapness, and accessibility is thus chosen by our group as support to achieve high-loading active Co nanoparticles. We reported that Co nanoparticle-decorated pomelo-peel-derived carbon (PP-Co) (Fig. 20(b)) was employed for electrochemical NO3 −RR, and the PP-Co catalyst achieved excellent catalytic performance for NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion [211]. Meanwhile, as for NO2 −RR, a hybrid of high-dispersed Co nanoparticles and Juncus-derived carbon (Co@JDC) [212] was successfully constructed for ambient NH3 production through electroreduction of NO2 − (Fig. 20(c)). The Co@JDC loaded on graphite felt (denoted as Co@JDC/GF) exhibited admirable NO2 −RR performance with a large NH3 yield of 2.8 ± 0.1 mol h−1 gCo −1 and a high FE of 96.9 ± 2.1% (Figs. 20(d) and 20(e)). Notably, the Co@JDC hybrid also performed well in electrochemical NO3 −RR and achieved a good NH3-generation performance (2.1 ± 0.1 mol h−1 gCo −1, 93.2 ± 4.8%). Besides, we fabricated a PV-electrolyzer reactor using Co@JDC/GF as a bifunctional electrode, and the assembled reactor achieved 12-h NH3 electrosynthesis powered by solar energy (Fig. 20(f)). DFT studies revealed that Co(111) has the highest catalytic activity and selectivity for electrochemical NO2 −RR among three Co crystal planes, which can conclude from the lower energy barriers of the rate-determining step (RDS) and the higher Gibbs free energy changes (ΔG) of the H atom on the Co(111) surface (Figs. 20(g) and 20(h)). In addition, our group [202] also employed highly stable TiO2 nanoarray as an alluring support to load active Co nanoparticles (Co@TiO2) for efficient electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3. The Co@TiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent NH3-generation efficiency with a FE of 96.7%, superior to the counterparts of Co (79.3%) and TiO2 (63.7%). DFT studies indicated that Co@TiO2 can boost the adsorption of NO3 − and the energy barrier of RDS on Co@TiO2 (*NH to *NH2, 0.69 eV) was smaller than on Co (*NH2 to *NH3, 0.99 eV) and TiO2 (*NH to *N, 1.26 eV). Su et al. [213] first reported that Ti plate-supported Co3O4 film (Co3O4/Ti) can serve as the cathode for electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction. The Co3O4/Ti electrode achieved good NO3 −-N removal and NH3-production efficiencies. Whereas, the catalytic ability of Co3O4 for electrochemical NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion is greatly limited by its low electroconductivity. To improve the electrocatalytic activity of Co3O4, our group proposed a series of modification strategies, such as vacancy engineering [214,215], heteroatoms doping [216], and constructing heterojunction [217]. For example, we [215] designed Co3O4 nanoarray with Co vacancies grown on CC substrate (vCo-Co3O4/CC) as a self-supported electrode for electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction to NH3 (Figs. 21(a) and 21(b) ). The experimental results showed that the vCo-Co3O4/CC catalyst performed better in electrochemical NO3 −RR than the Co3O4/CC catalyst (Figs. 21(c) and 21(d)). Furthermore, DFT calculations manifested that the introduction of Co vacancies regulated the electron structure of Co3O4, leading to the increase in charge at the active sites, thus optimizing the adsorption energy of NO3 − and reducing the energy barrier of PDS (*NHO to *NHOH) (Fig. 21(e)), resulting in high catalytic perfoemance. Similarly, we [216] adopted Fe as a dopant to modulate the electron structure of Co3O4, further improving its NO3 −RR performance. Theoretical calculations manifested that the Fe atom was more likely to replace the 5-coordination (5C) Co atom, and the adsorption of NO3 − on Fe-Co3O4(311)-5C was stronger than pristine Co3O4(311), demonstrating the higher activity of Fe-Co3O4 for NO3 −RR. Besides, we further [217] constructed a Co3O4@TiO2 heterojunction catalyst for electrocatalytic NO3 −RR. A built-in electric field formed at the heterointerface between Co3O4 and TiO2, which can optimize the electron migration kinetics and contribute to capturing NO3 − on the near surface of the electrocatalyst, thus ensuring the selectivity to NH3. Consequently, the as-designed catalyst delivered excellent NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion performance (93.1%, 875 μmol h−1 cm−2) in alkaline media, superior to the counterparts of Co3O4 and TiO2. DFT calculations manifested that coupling Co3O4 with TiO2 can modulate the electronic structure and significantly enhance the overall conductivity of Co3O4@TiO2, leading to better catalytic activity. Further, the PDS was confirmed as the conversion of *NO to *N on Co3O4@TiO2, and the HER activity on Co3O4@TiO2 can be effectively suppressed. In a theoretical study by Zhou's group [218], they found that Co(III) and Co(II) acted in different roles in NO3 − reduction. In detail, Co(III) preferred providing empty d orbitals, but Co(II) favored transferring electrons to reduce NO3 −. Inspired by this, we prepared [219] CoO@NCNT as a NO3RR catalyst (Figs. 21(f) and 21(g)), and the catalyst showed excellent NH3-production efficiency with a peak FE of 93.8 ± 1.5% and a yield of 9041.6 ± 370.7 μg h−1 cm−2. Besides, DFT calculations showed that the NO3 − can be efficiently reduced to NH3 on the CoO surface (Figs. 21(h)–21(j)). CoP nanomaterials have been proven the high catalytic activity for facilitating NO x −-to-NH3 conversion [220,221]. Our group successfully prepared Ti mesh-supported CoP nanoarray (CoP NA/TM) (Fig. 22(a) ) by treating Co(OH)F NA/TM precursor with a phosphating process [221]. The CoP NA/TM catalyst exhibited excellent NH3-generation performance with a high NH3 yield (2260.7 ± 51.5 μg h−1 cm−2) and FE (90.0 ± 2.3%) in neutral electrolyte with 0.1 M PBS and 500 ppm NO2 − (Fig. 22(b)). Theoretical calculations unveiled that CoP(112) can effectively suppress HER and promote NO2 −-to-NH3 conversion. Liu's group [222] reported CoP nanosheet arrays on carbon fiber cloth (CoP NAs/CFC) applied for electrochemical NO3 −RR. The CoP NAs/CFC electrocatalyst achieved a remarkable FE (nearly 100%) and a respectable NH3 yield, which was superior to the Co NAs/CFC counterpart. The Operando XANES results revealed that the prerequisite for NO3 − reduction on CoP was the electrons excitation from Co 3d orbitals to Co 4p orbitals (induced by enough electric field) so that the excited electrons can be further injected into the π* orbitals of NO3 − via the Co−O−N bond, thus destabilizing and reducing the adsorbed NO3 − (Figs. 22(c) and 22(d)). Additionally, it was found that metallic Co changed into Co(OH)2 during the NO3 −RR process because NO3 − can serve as the oxidant and the application of cathodic potential enhances the phase conversion (Figs. 22(e) and 22(f)). DTF calculations manifested that the insertion of P can reduce the energy barrier of RDS, boosting the NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion (Fig. 22(g)). Recently, Fan et al. [223] reported CoP nanosphere assembled on a carbon nanosheet array (CoP-CNS) as a NO3 −RR catalyst, and the enhanced NO3 −RR performance was achieved by balancing the generation and consumption of Hads over the CoP-CNS electrode. The experimental results demonstrated that CoP had a stronger ability to produce and hold Hads than Co, and OH− was beneficial to the accumulation of Hads, while NO3 − promoted the consumption of Hads. DTF calculations suggested the ΔG of RDS on the CoP(211) surface was far lower than the Co(111) surface (1.57 eV vs. 3.09 eV), meaning the higher NO3 −RR activity of CoP-CNS. This research provides a novel perspective based on Hads dynamic equilibrium for catalyst design. Besides, to further enhance the electrocatalytic activity of CoP, our group [224] successfully constructed a p-n heterojunction of CoP/TiO2 as a NO3 −RR catalyst for NH3 electrosynthesis (Figs. 22(h) and 22(i)). The as-designed catalyst displayed an excellent NH3-generation efficiency with a high FE of 95.0% and showed impressive durability during recycling tests and 50-h bulk electrolysis. DFT results revealed that the conversion of NO3 − to *NO3 − was confirmed as the PDS and the HER activity on CoP/TiO2 can be greatly suppressed. The excellent catalytic activities of binary Co-based spinel oxides (such as NiCo2O4 [225], ZnCo2O4 [226], Co2AlO4 [203], FeCo2O4 [227], etc.) for electrochemical NO3 −RR to produce NH3 were studied and confirmed by our group. We [225] first developed a self-supported NiCo2O4 catalyst grown on CC substrate (NiCo2O4/CC) for electroreduction NO3 − to NH3. The NiCo2O4/CC electrocatalyst showed a larger current density gap during the NO3 −RR process, compared to the Co3O4/CC counterpart, which implied the superior NO3 −RR activity of NiCo2O4/CC (Fig. 23(a) ). Moreover, such a catalyst exhibited admirable NO3 −RR performance with an ultrahigh FE of 99.0% and a high NH3-production rate of 973.2 µmol h−1 cm−2 (Fig. 23(b)), superior to Co3O4/CC. We assembled a NiCo2O4/CC-based Zn-NO3 − battery and such a battery system can deliver a peak power density of up to 3.94 mW·cm−2 (Figs. 23(c) and 23(d)). Theoretical studies indicated that the higher catalytic activity of NiCo2O4 (with the half-metal feature) than Co3O4 (with semiconductor feature) can be attributed to the improved electronic structures. Meanwhile, DFT calculations further revealed that the energy barrier of PDS on NiCo2O4(311) was far lower than Co3O4(311) (Fig. 23(e)), and the HER activity on the NiCo2O4(311) surface can be severely suppressed. Besides, we [226] reported a ZnCo2O4 nanosheet array grown on CC substrate (ZnCo2O4 NSA/CC) as a cost-effective NO3 −RR electrocatalyst for NH3 synthesis. The as-prepared catalyst showed higher NO3 −RR activity and performed better in NH3 production than the Co3O4 counterpart (634.74 vs. 379.01 µmol h−1 cm−2, 98.33% vs. 92.42%) in alkaline media (Figs. 23(f) and 23(g)). Moreover, the theoretical studies also indicated that the ZnCo2O4(311) surface had superior selectivity and activity for electrochemical NO3 −RR. Because of the high abundance of metallic Al in the earth's crust, our group [203] further explored the catalytic ability of Co2AlO4 nanoarray on CC substrate (Co2AlO4/CC) toward electrochemical NO3 −RR (Figs. 23(h) and 23(i)). The Co2AlO4/CC catalyst presented excellent NO3 −RR activity and respectable NH3-generation performance with a peak FE of 92.6% and a maximum NH3-production rate of 7.9 mg h−1 cm−2. DTF calculations manifested that the electron cloud density of Co on Co2AlO4(220) was lower than on Co3O4(220), making the stronger NO3 − adsorption on Co2AlO4(220). Additionally, the reduction of *NO3 to *NO3H was identified as the PDS with a low energy barrier of 0.42 eV. Given the admirable catalytic activity of Fe, we developed a self-supported FeCo2O4 catalyst for electrochemically converting NO3 − into NH3 [227]. As expected, the as-prepared catalyst exhibited admirable NO3 −RR activity and obtained excellent NH3-generation efficiency, much superior to the counterparts of Co3O4 and Fe2O3. Furthermore, the NO3 −RR activities of MnCo2O4 electrocatalyst [228] and Mn2CoO4 electrocatalyst [229] were also investigated by our group and both exhibited exceptional catalytic performance for NO3 −-to-NH3 transformation. These findings open new avenues to design and develop Co-based spinel oxides as NO3 −RR electrocatalysts for efficient NH3 production. Amorphous materials possess many advantages of structural flexibility, abundant defects, and unique electronic property [230,231], which can greatly improve electrocatalytic performance and would be potential materials for facilitating NO x −-to-NH3 conversion. Our group [232] demonstrated that Co-P alloy film electrodeposited on Ti plate (Co-P/TP) can serve as an effective catalyst for NH3 electrosynthesis via NO3 −RR (Fig. 24(a) ) and NO2 −RR (Fig. 24(b)). Furthermore, a long-term electrolysis test performed in 0.2 M Na2SO4 electrolyte containing 200 ppm NO3 −, the Co-P/TP catalyst can obtain a respectable conversion rate of 86.9% after 10-h electrolysis (Fig. 24(c)). Shi et al.
