[233] successfully synthesized amorphous CoB x nanoparticles by a facile and rapid wet-chemical reduction method (Fig. 24(d)) and further investigated the electrochemical NO3 −RR performance under alkaline media (0.787 ± 0.028 mmol h−1 cm−2, 94.0 ± 1.67%). The amorphous CoB x catalyst had higher catalytic activity and NH3-generation performance than the counterpart of metallic Co (Figs. 24(e) and 24(f)), which can be ascribed to the modulation of the electronic structure of Co, causing higher intrinsic activity of CoB x . To further obtain enhanced NO3 −RR performance, our group [234] prepared an amorphous Co2B layer on Co3O4 nanoarray/Ti mesh (Co2B@Co3O4/TM) as a NO3 −RR catalyst for electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3. Such a catalyst reached admirable NH3-production efficiency with an extremely high FE of 97.0%, superior to the counterparts of Co3O4/TM (89.3%), Co2B/TM (83.5%), and bare TM (39.0%) (Fig. 24(g)). DFT studies indicated that the reduction of *NO2H to *NO was identified as the PDS (Fig. 24(h)). In addition, we also constructed amorphous CoB deposited on Ti plate-supported TiO2 nanoarray (CoB@TiO2/TP) as a NO2 −RR catalyst for NH3 electrosynthesis [230]. The CoB@TiO2/TP catalyst presented an excellent FE of 95.2% and an NH3 yield of 293 μmol h−1 cm−2. These studies offer conducive guidance to develop cost-effective electrocatalysts based on amorphous materials for NH3 production via NO3 −RR/NO2 −RR. Recently, Cu-based nanomaterials have exhibited admirable catalytic activity for selectively converting NO3 − into NH3 [235–237]. Chen et al. [238] reported that Cu incorporated in 3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (Cu-PTCDA) can direct electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3, and the Cu-PTCDA exhibited the highest FE among all the synthesized metal-molecular solid electrocatalysts for converting NO3 − to NO2 −/NH3 (Fig. 25(a) ). The projected density of states (PDOS) of Cu-PTCDA exhibited an extremely high degree of hybridization of O and Cu atoms (Fig. 25(b)). Besides, the isolated Cu site and coordinated Cu–N bonds were verified by HADDF-STEM and EXAFS, respectively (Figs. 25(c) and 25(d)). In neutral media, the Cu-PTCDA catalyst achieved the highest FE of 85.9% for NH3 production (Fig. 25(e)). The admirable performance of Cu-PTCDA was ascribed to the enhanced transfer of protons and/or electrons to the active Cu centers and the suppressed HER. In addition, based on DFT calculations, Guo and co-workers [239] methodically investigated the NO3 −-to-NH3 reaction pathways on three typical Cu crystal planes at various pH and determined the most probable reaction pathway. Besides, theoretical results also ascertained the suitable pH range for NO3 −RR on different Cu crystal planes. Both Cu(100) and Cu(111) showed superior NO3 −RR activity than Cu(100), and Cu(111) displayed the most outstanding catalytic performance for NO3 −RR in neutral and alkaline media, while Cu(100) performed well in strong acidic media. Fu and colleagues [240] reported that Cu nanosheets achieved excellent NH3-generation performance with an ultrahigh FE of 99.7% and a large NH3 yield of 390.1 µg mgCu −1 h−1 under ambient conditions. The admirable catalytic ability of Cu nanosheets toward NO3 −RR can be ascribed to the inhibited HER activity and the improved rate of RDS on Cu(111). These findings provide vital guidance in catalyst design based on crystal facet engineering for efficient NH3 production. As for NO2 −RR, our group [241] synthesized a hybrid of high-dispersed Cu nanoparticles and Juncus-derived carbon (Cu@JDC) for electrocatalytic NO2 −RR to NH3, and the catalyst achieved excellent NH3-generation performance (93.2%, 523.5 µmol h−1 mgcat. −1) in alkaline conditions. DFT calculations suggested that Cu(111) possessed the best NO2 −RR activity than other Cu crystal planes, and the competitive HER can be effectively suppressed on the Cu(111) surface, resulting in high NH3 FE. To further enhance the electrocatalytic activity of Cu toward NO2 −RR, we [242] successfully constructed the Schottky junction by integrating metallic Cu nanoparticles into TiO2 nanobelt array (Cu@TiO2). As expected, the as-designed catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity and admirable NH3-production efficiency (95.3%), far superior to the counterparts of Cu (85.8%) and TiO2 (82.1%). Besides, we [243] first investigated the NO2 −RR performance of a Cu foam-supported Cu3P nanowire array (Cu3P NA/CF). The catalyst performed well in electrochemical NO2 −-to-NH3 conversion, achieving a peak FE of 91.2 ± 2.5% with a respectable NH3 yield of 1626.6 ± 36.1 μg h−1 cm−2 in neutral media. Moreover, the Cu3P NA/CF catalyst also exhibited good NH3-production performance (848.7 ± 18.0 μg h−1 cm−2, 62.9 ± 2.0%) during the electrochemical NO3 −RR process. In a recent study, our group [244] reported Cu foam-supported Cu2O nanoparticles (CF@Cu2O) with oxygen vacancies (OVs) as a NO2 −RR catalyst, and the catalyst obtained a respectable NO2 −RR performance. Theoretical calculations indicated that the Cu2O(111) surface with OVs can boost the adsorption and activation of NO2 −, conducive to further electrochemical reduction (Figs. 26(a) and 26(b) ). The energy barrier of RDS on the Cu2O(111) surface with OVs was far lower than on the pristine Cu2O(111) surface (0.05 eV vs. 0.41 eV) (Fig. 26(c)), revealing the vital role of OVs formed on the Cu2O(111) surface during the electrocatalytic NO2 −RR process. Noteworthily, Cu-based nanomaterials are inclined to surface reconstruction during the electroreduction process, thus it is important to probe the active origin and structure evolution during the electrochemical reaction process for both fundamental understanding and rational design of Cu-based catalysts for NH3 electrosynthesis. In this regard, Zhang's group [197] developed CuO nanowire arrays as a cost-effective NO3 −RR electrocatalyst and applied in situ characterization techniques to unveil the active phase of CuO electrocatalyst. Experimental results suggested that CuO was electrochemically reduced to Cu/Cu2O heterostructure during NO3 −RR electrocatalysis, which is the real active phase. Theoretical calculations further unveiled that Cu/Cu2O can effectively inhibit the competing HER and significantly promote NO3 − electroreduction. Additionally, Yang et al. [245] discovered the restructuring of Cu-N4 single-atom sites during the electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3 by using operando XAS coupling with advanced electron microscopy (Figs. 26(d)–26(f)). Specifically, the as-synthesized Cu-N4 structure experienced the sequential evolution from Cu-N3 to near-free Cu0 single atoms and eventually to aggregated Cu0 nanoparticles during the electrochemical NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion. Moreover, the aggregated Cu0 nanoparticles can be dismantled into single atoms and again restored to the Cu–N4 structure upon being exposed to an ambient atmosphere after the electrolysis. Fe-based nanomaterials, such as Fe SAC [246], Fe3C nanoflakes [247], FeB2 nanorod [248], Fe3O4 particles [249], etc. are capable of effectively facilitating electrochemical NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion. Our group [249] fabricated Fe3O4 particles on stainless steel (Fe3O4/SS) (Fig. 27(a) ) by in situ growth strategy as a self-supported catalyst for electrochemical NO3 −RR. The Fe3O4/SS catalyst exhibited outstanding NO3 −RR activity and achieved satisfactory NH3-generation performance with a peak FE of 91.5% and a high NH3 yield of 10145 μg h−1 cm−2, superior to the SS (Fig. 27(b)). Theoretical calculations revealed that the Fe3O4(311) surface was beneficial for the capture and reduction of NO3 −, and the energy barrier of PDS (*NO2 to *NO2H) just required 0.13 eV. This finding expands the scope of Fe-based catalysts for electrocatalytic NO3 −RR. In another work, we [250] exhibited FeOOH nanorod with Ovacancy as an active NO3 −RR catalyst for NH3 electrosynthesis, obtaining a high FE (92%) and NH3 yield (2419 μg h−1 cm−2) in neutral media. Theoretical results manifested the energy barrier of *NO3 adsorption on the FeOOH (200) surface with Ovacancy was lower than on the pristine FeOOH (200) surface (−0.02 vs. 0.29 eV), verifying the high NO3 −RR activity of FeOOH with Ovacancy. Furthermore, we [251] also prepared an FeOOH nanotube array grown on CC substrate (FeOOH NTA/CC) with high stability as a cost-effective catalyst for NO2 − electroreduction to NH3 (Fig. 27(c)). The electrocatalyst can attain admirable NH3-production performance (94.7%, 11937 μg h−1 cm−2) in neutral media (Fig. 27(d)). Recently, a FeS2@TiO2 nanobelt array (Fig. 27(e)) was successfully prepared by our group and employed for electrochemical NO3 −RR to produce NH3 [252]. The FeS2@TiO2 catalyst exhibited superior NH3-generation performance (97.0%, 330.3 μmol h−1 cm−2) than that of FeS2 and TiO2 (Fig. 27(f)). Theoretical calculations unveiled that the energy barrier of PDS on FeS2@TiO2 (*NO to *NOH, 0.62 eV) was far smaller than on pristine TiO2 (*NOH to *N, 1.02 eV), suggesting the high NO3 −RR activity on FeS2@TiO2. Besides, Li and colleagues [253] prepared Fe2TiO5 nanofibers with Ovacancy by electrospinning technology and calcination treatment as an active NO3 −RR catalyst. The catalyst achieved excellent NO3 −RR performance (87.6%, 0.73 mmol h−1 mgcat. −1) under ambient conditions, superior to the other three catalysts (Figs. 28(a) and 28(b) ). Moreover, the catalyst was also active for electrochemically converting NO2 − into NH3 and can attain a brilliant NH3 yield (1.36 mmol h−1 mgcat. −1) and FE (96.06%). DFT calculations exhibited that the conductivity of the as-prepared catalyst was significantly enhanced by Ovacancy and unveiled that the adsorption ability of NO3 − on the Fe2TiO5(110) surface with Ovacancy was stronger than on the pristine Fe2TiO5(110) surface, and the reduction of *NO to *N was determined as the PDS (Figs. 28(c)–28(e)). Ni-based electrocatalysts have attracted much attention for ambient NH3 production via the electrochemical NtrRR process. Yao et al. [254] successfully synthesized Ni2P with (111) surface on Ni foam (denoted as NFP) by a one-step phosphating process, acting as a NO3 −RR electrocatalyst. The catalyst exhibited excellent removal efficiency of NO3 − (86.6%), high NH3 selectivity (89.1%), and admirable NH3 FE (99.23%), superior to the other three counterparts (Fig. 29(a) ). DFT calculations suggested that the Ni2P(111) surface with the lowest surface energy was more stable than that of Ni2P(201), Ni2P(210), and Ni2P(211) surfaces and all deoxygenation and hydrogenation steps on the Ni2P(111) surface were exothermic processes (Fig. 29(b)). Our group [255] employed Ni foam-supported Ni2P nanoarray (Ni2P/NF) as an active catalyst for electrochemically converting NO2 − into NH3. The Ni2P/NF catalyst possessed excellent catalytic ability for NO2 − electroreduction, which can obtain great NO2 −RR performance with a high NH3 yield (2692.2 ± 92.1 μg h−1 cm−2), an excellent FE (90.2 ± 3.0%), and a good NH3 selectivity (87.0 ± 1.7%) in neutral electrolyte containing 200 ppm NO2 − (Figs. 29(c) and 29(d)). By performing the DFT calculations, the Ni2P(111) plane was identified as the optimum active site. Besides, the NO2 −RR activities of Ni nanoparticle-decorated Juncus-derived biomass carbon (Ni@JBC) [256] and NiS2@TiO2 nanoribbon array [257] were also confirmed by our group. TiO2 has the features of eco-friendliness, abundance, and corrosion resistance, and significant efforts have been put into designing and developing TiO2-based NRR catalysts for NH3 electrosynthesis [69–80]. But until recently, Jia et al. [258] first demonstrated the outstanding NO3 −RR performance of TiO2 nanotubes with Ovacancy (TiO2−x ), and the catalyst showed a brilliant NH3 yield of 0.045 mmol h−1 mg−1 with an excellent FE of 85.0%, a high NH3 selectivity of 87.1%, and an ideal NO3 − conversion rate of 95.2% (Fig. 30(a) ). The DEMS and DFT results (Figs. 30(b) and 30(c)) revealed the important function of Ovacancy in electrocatalytic NO3 −RR. Concretely, the O in NO3 − can fill in the Ovacancy site to weaken the N−O bond and inhibit the generation of by-products, thus showing high FE and selectivity for NH3 electrosynthesis. Besides, our group [259] verified the excellent NH3-production performance of oxygen-vacancy-enriched TiO2 nanobelt array grown on a Ti plate (TiO2−x NBA/TP) during the electrocatalytic NO2 −RR process. Except for oxygen vacancy engineering, other effective strategies have also been developed by our group to boost the catalytic performance of TiO2 for electrochemically converting NO3 −/NO2 − into NH3, such as combing with high-conductivity ITO (ITO@TiO2 [260]), crystal structures regulation (Anatase TiO2−x [261]), and heteroatom doping (Fe-TiO2 [262], Co-TiO2 [263], V-TiO2 [264], Ni-TiO2 [265]) and P-TiO2 [266]). Our group [263] detailedly investigated the NO3 −RR activity of Co-doped TiO2, and the catalyst achieved excellent NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion efficiency (98.2%) in alkaline media, superior to the pristine TiO2 (35.1%), suggesting Co-doping is an effective strategy to boost the electrocatalytic NO3 −RR performance of TiO2. Additionally, the NO2 −RR mechanism of V-doped TiO2 was also investigated by our group at an atomic scale [264]. Theoretical calculations revealed that introducing V into TiO2 can greatly improve the intrinsic electrical conductivity of the catalyst and accelerate the PDS (Fig. 30(d)), resulting in improved NO2 −RR activity. Besides, the experimental results indicated that the catalytic activity of TiO2 can be dramatically improved by V doping, and the V-TiO2 catalyst achieved superior NH3-production efficiency than pristine TiO2 (93.2% vs. 80.5%) in alkaline media. Moreover, the catalyst obtained an admirable NO2 − conversion rate of 95.3% in 0.1 mol L−1 NaOH electrolyte containing 20 mmol NO2 − after 24 h of electrolysis. These findings offer helpful guidance for rationally constructing TiO2-based electrocatalysts for efficiently converting NO3 −/NO2 − into value-added NH3. Overall, electrochemically converting NO3 −/NO2 − contaminants into high-value NH3 should be a sustainable and effective route for ambient NH3 production. At present, the high-efficiency electrocatalysts for NtrRR were almost identified from simulated electrolytes containing NO3 − or NO2 − (i.e., NaOH + NaNO3/NaNO2, PBS + NaNO3/NaNO2, Na2SO4 + NaNO3/NaNO2, etc.), rather than real wastewater. However, the overall composition of real wastewater is complex, which may form a potential hindrance to efficient NH3 production. Therefore, future research works are suggested to assess the NtrRR performance of electrocatalysts in real wastewater, and the possible effects of other ions consisting in real wastewater also need to be considered. 6 Conclusion and outlook Human activities have caused the natural N-cycle imbalance to some extent, which has negative impacts on natural ecosystems and meanwhile threatens human survival. Therefore, the development of effective and sustainable solutions to mitigate the current environmental problem is truly essential. With the tremendous development of clean renewable electricity, electrocatalysis is deemed as a viable route to sustainably convert some N-containing compounds (i.e., N2, NO, and NO3 −/NO2 −) to value-added NH3 for artificial N-cycle. In this Account, we highlight the recent advances in designing and developing high-efficiency electrocatalysts for ambient NH3 synthesis, involving catalytic mechanisms, theoretical advances, and electrochemical performance. Although the research in this field has made considerable progress over the years, there remain certain issues and challenges in developing high-performance electrocatalysts to produce NH3, and the following aspects in this field need to be further considered. (1) Pay attention to theoretical calculation. Theoretical calculations have been proven as a powerful approach for catalyst screening. The possible active sites, adsorption energies, and reaction pathways can be predicted in advance by theoretical calculations, which contributes to quickly screening out suitable catalysts, greatly cutting down the experimental costs. (2) Development of advanced in situ/operando characterization techniques can significantly contribute to revealing the reaction intermediates, and the real active sites on the catalyst surface during the electrocatalytic process. Since the electrode surface may undergo surface reconstruction under realistic operating conditions and post-experiment characterization may not display the real catalyst surface under the exposure of air. Therefore, directly capturing and identifying the reaction intermediates and the dynamic changes on the electrocatalyst surface using in situ/operando characterization techniques are greatly necessary, which will aid in deepening understanding of reaction pathways and catalytic structure-property relationships, further guiding new direction for catalyst design. (3) Ensure data accuracy and reproducibility. Establishing a complete and precise quantitative analysis system for electrocatalytic NH3 production to ensure data reliability is highly important. At present, the spectrophotometric assay is most popular for NH3 detection because of the advantages of cheap, simple operation, and great sensitivity. Whereas, some interference factors (e.g., the pH, ion concentration, reaction time, etc.) would disturb the accuracy of the spectrophotometric assay, thus affecting the data reliability. As well-developed detection techniques, both ion chromatography and 1H NMR measurement are regarded as reliable alternatives to achieve more accurate NH3 quantification. Moreover, the requisite blank/control experiments are highly suggested to eliminate possible N-containing contaminations from the electrolysis cell, electrocatalyst, electrolyte, experimental consumables, and even ambient air, so that guarantee the detected NH3 indeed attributes to the electrocatalytic process. (4) Rational design of effective electrocatalysts. To further improve the catalytic performance of the existing material system toward NH3 synthesis, more efficient material design strategies (such as accurately regulating the coordination environment of single atom metals, the type and concentration of doping atom/vacancy, rationally exposing specific crystal facet, etc.) should be developed for facilitating the intrinsic activity of electrocatalysts. In addition, optimizing the morphology of electrocatalysts to create special structures (such as sharp spikes) can expose abundant active sites, significantly promoting their apparent activity and facilitating subsequent electrocatalysis. (5) When investigating a specific electrode material, except materials engineering, expanded experimental conditions should also be critical, including pH value of the electrolyte, applied potential, initial concentration of nitrogen resource, and temperature, which may affect the catalytic activity and selectivity of the electrochemical process. (6) The commonly reported stability tests in the literature are usually under 50 h, which is a too short duration for industrial implementation where thousands of hours of stable operation at high current density are expected. Therefore, the future protocol for catalyst durability needs to aim for much longer test times. (7) The electrocatalytic activity of NORR or NtrRR is suggested to be investigated in a real environment. In fact, the overall composition of real exhaust gases or wastewater is complex, so the investigations cannot only perform in simulated electrolytes to assess the electrocatalytic performance of catalysts. Future studies should further explore the catalytic activity in a real environment to enable more efficient NH3 production. (8) An alternative technique for NH3 separation should be developed. In the conventional Haber-Bosch process, NH3 is separated from the unreacted N2 and H2 by condensation, which is energy-consuming and only applicable for large-scale and centralized NH3 production. In a renewable energy-driven, small scale and distributed plant, NH3 synthesis is usually conducted under lower temperatures and pressures. NH3 yield is much less than the Haber-Bosch process, so an alternative NH3 separation technique with less energy input than the condensation process should be adopted. (9) From the point of view of practical application, a comprehensive techno-economic assessment including material costs, overall energy costs, equipment maintenance costs, product separation costs, etc., should also be considered to reveal the scalability and commercial viability for large-scale NH3 electrosynthesis. Xuping Sun received his PhD degree in Changchun Institute of Applied Chemistry (CIAC), Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2006. During 2006–2009, he carried out postdoctoral researches at Konstanz University, University of Toronto, and Purdue University. In 2010, he started his independent research career as a full Professor at CIAC and then moved to Sichuan University in 2015. In 2018, he joined University of Electronic Science and Technology of China where he found the Research Center of Nanocatalysis & Sensing. He was recognized as a highly cited researcher (2018–2020) in both areas of chemistry and materials science by Clarivate Analytics. He published over 600 papers with total citations over 65000 and an h-index of 132. His research mainly focuses on rational design of nanocatalysts toward applications in electrosynthesis of green hydrogen and ammonia as well as electrochemical denitration of vehicle exhausts and industrial wastewater. Binwu Ying , MD, Postdoc, MBA, Professor, doctoral supervisor. Vice President of West China College of Medical Technology, Sichuan University, Director of Department of Laboratory Medicine, West China Clinical Medical College/West China Hospital Department of Laboratory Medicine. Standing member of the 11th Committee of the Chinese Medical Association Laboratory Medicine Committee, Standing member of the 4th Laboratory Medicine Branch of the Chinese Medical Doctor Association, Chairman of the 12th Clinical Laboratory Medicine Committee of the Sichuan Medical Association, and president-elect of the 3rd Laboratory Medicine branch of the Sichuan Medical Doctor Association. Senior editorial board member of Chinese Chemical Letters, the editorial board member of Chinese Medical Journal, and the editorial board members of Chinese Journal of Laboratory Medicine, Journal of Sichuan University (Medical Edition), International Journal of Laboratory Science. He is mainly engaged in molecular diagnostic research of infectious diseases. He has published more than 200 papers and won 10 national invention patents.

coredata.dc:description: Artificial electrocatalytic ammonia (NH3) synthesis is recently becoming a research hotspot. It can couple with clean renewable electricity, which is considered an energy-efficient and sustainable approach for regulating the recirculation of nitrogen species and meanwhile promoting the growth of a circular nitrogen economy. In this Account, we review recent advances in electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis. Firstly, we briefly introduce the research background and significance of three electrochemical NH3 synthesis routes: electrocatalytic nitrogen reduction, nitric oxide reduction, and nitrate/nitrite reduction. And then we give a detailed discussion of the latest research advances in electrocatalysts for ambient NH3 synthesis, mainly involving catalytic mechanisms, theoretical advances, and electrochemical performance. Finally, the existing challenges and future research needs for artificial electrosynthesis of NH3 are also highlighted.
